column8: A documentary short film featuring one of the earliest gay pride demonstration marches, the first Christopher Street Liberation Day March, held in New York, New York, on June 28, 1970, to commemorate the first anniversary of the Stonewall Riots. Covering about fifty blocks and drawing just a few thousand participants, it and marches like it held the same year in Chicago, San Francisco, and Los Angeles eventually led to hundreds of Pride parades throughout the world in the following decades.

column8: Excerpts featuring Fr. Robert Mary Clement and John Darcy Noble's participation in the first Christopher Street Liberation Day March. Clips taken from a documentary short film featuring one of the earliest gay pride demonstration marches, the first Christopher Street Liberation Day March, held in New York, New York, on June 28, 1970, to commemorate the first anniversary of the Stonewall Riots. Covering about fifty blocks and drawing just a few thousand participants, it and marches like it held the same year in Chicago, San Francisco, and Los Angeles eventually led to hundreds of Pride parades throughout the world in the following decades.

column29: Excerpts of Clement and Noble from time 03:28-03:35 and 10:09-10:24 in the original documentary.
column30:
[crowd chanting] 

Reporter: What is the American Church? 
Clement: It’s a sacramental catholic church devoted to the needs of gay people. It’s a homophile community.

[crowds chanting]

[voice over from an interview with another parade participant…]
